newsitem.title: USA: K-III to offer non-core units for sale.
newsitem.headline: K-III to offer non-core units for sale.

text.p: K-III Communications Corp., a magazine publisher and mass media company, said Tuesday it would restructure, offering non-core units for sale and focusing on six high-growth businesses for the future.

Chairman and Chief Executive Officer William Reilly said the company would put up for sale Daily Racing Form and Pro-Football Weekly, Newbridge Book Clubs, New Woman Magazine and Krames Communications.
Those four businesses represent about 19 percent of 1996 revenues of $1.37 billion, he said.
Proceeds from the sales will be used to reduce debt and preferred stock. The company previously announced that it intends to sell Katherine Gibbs Schools.
Reilly said the company will focus on businesses in markets with projected growth of at least two times that of Gross Domestic Product.

The company will focus on its Workplace learning (Westcott); classroom learning (Channel One and Weekly Reader); speciality consumer magazines (Seventeen, Soap Opera Digest, Truckin', Crafts); technical and trade magazines (Ward's, Telephony); consumer directories (Apartment Guides, World Almanac), and business directories (Pacific Shipper, Bacon's).
"All of these businesses provide strong opportunities for organic growth and can be supplemented with product add-on acquisitions funded in part through our strong cash flow," said Reilly.
Separately, K-III said it planned a public offering of about 12.5 million shares. It said it anticipated the offering would be made in April.
Net proceeds will be used to redeem the company's outstanding $2.875 senior exchangeable preferred stock and to repay debt, the company said.
K-III stock was off 25 cents at $12.375 in morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
